snippet: Chesapeake Energy announced that it would replace Aubrey K. McClendon as chairman and end his controversial compensation plan.
abstract: Chesapeake Energy announces that it will replace Aubrey K McClendon as chairman and end his controversial compensation plan that grants him the right to buy a 2.5 percent stake in every well the company drills; McClendon, who built Chesapeake into the nation's second-largest producer of natural gas, will remain as chief executive; board will seek to appoint a nonexecutive chairman with no ties to the company. Photo (M)

byline.original: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED; Clifford Krauss reported from Houston and Michael J. de la Merced from New York

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON -- Aubrey K. McClendon built Chesapeake Energy into the nation's second-largest producer of natural gas through a combination of debt, foresight, luck and sheer bravado. Now both he and the company have been forced to add humility to the mix.
